section.title: Active
section.para: An active component is one that is fully committed, currently in use, and visible throughout the application. This status represents the default “live” state for any concept or semantic, meaning the component is displayed across all panels and is accessible to users. On the backend, active components are fully committed, included in all indexes, and exported as part of the system’s data outputs.

section.title: Inactive
section.para: An inactive component is one that has been explicitly marked as no longer active but is retained within the system for historical and traceability purposes. This status is used when a component is superseded, deprecated, or needs to be hidden from active use while still remaining viewable for reference. Inactive components are shown with an inactive status and are visible in history views and filters. On the backend, they are retained with all historical versions and are included in exports and audit logs.

section.title: Withdrawn
section.para: A withdrawn component is one that was released by mistake and must be treated as if it never existed, such as in cases of copyright violation, data breach, or legal removal. This is a rare status, typically invoked under legal or policy mandates. Withdrawn components are hidden from normal views and do not appear in searches or history unless specifically surfaced. Although they still exist in the database, they are treated as “voided” and do not appear in exports, indexes, or history trails. Importantly, a withdrawn status is permanent and should never be recovered to active or inactive; it is distinct from inactive because it fully suppresses visibility and treats the component as retracted from the system.

section.title: Canceled
section.para: A canceled component refers to a temporary or uncommitted component or version that was abandoned before being committed to the system. This occurs when a user cancels a creation or exits the application without saving changes. Canceled components are never visible in the application and are filtered from all user-facing views. On the backend, they exist only in a transient state, marked with a “canceled” stamp, and are subject to garbage collection and cleanup. They are not included in exports.

section.title: Retired (Deprecated Term)
section.para: The term “retired” was previously used informally or in reference to external standards, such as SNOMED or LOINC, but it is not a valid or supported status in Komet. It is recommended to avoid using “retired” to describe a component’s state and to use “inactive” instead. There is no user interface or backend recognition of “retired” as a formal status.
